The @MiamiHerald and @elnuevoherald partnered with @InfoAmazonia, @RunRunesWeb, @CorreodelCaroni and @decorrespondent on this series, which was aided by the Human Rights Foundation and the Dutch Fund for Journalism Projects. #SmugglersParadise

After hopscotching across the Caribbean, Venezuelan gold is landing in world-class refineries thousands of miles away. The refineries are inadvertently laundering ‘blood gold’ while obscuring the devastation surrounding its origins. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/2YaGWRN

The private and commercial planes flying over sunburned tourists have been dropping off thousands of pounds of Venezuelan gold, according to airport operators, customs officials and government sources. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/30QLfDy

It’s hard to fully grasp the scope of Venezuela’s gold trade. Less than 50 miles away from Venezuela, the shiny Caribbean beaches of Curaçao and Aruba have become much more than tourist destinations. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/7r0H4gQsAE

A 2017 study found that communities living along Colombia’s Atabapo, Guainía and Inírida rivers, near the Venezuelan mines, had about 60 times the maximum safe level of mercury recommended by the World Health Organization. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/2SvvEX2

South America’s indigenous people also aren’t spared. Illegal gold mining is destroying the rainforest, and toxic mercury — used to bind gold flakes — is poisoning the region’s water supply. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/vL1EdXPHwu
Trying to evade those tolls can be deadly. ‘If they want to collect, you pay or die,’ said a former Venezuelan soldier who now smuggles gold. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/2Yd57ii
Many refugees end up having to smuggle gold, bribing their way through National Guard and guerrilla checkpoints to get the metal to the Colombian border. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/XQydWhbls6

It’s not just the military. Venezuelan crime syndicates and Colombian armed groups also have their hands in the illegal gold trade. For those trying to escape Maduro’s rule, the groups have one thing in common: They make the journey out of Venezuela dangerous. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/EjvPjxpll2
“The military arrived to do business, not to protect the citizens. Every week there is a murder,” one businessman said. #SmugglersParadisehttps://hrld.us/2Yc47Lp

American consumers are unwitting players in a vicious game. Organized crime groups and members of Maduro’s National Guard have taken over villages and turned them into gold mining hells, exploiting workers and killing residents with impunity. #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/btMK7dAMdB

America’s demand for the precious metal is helping fuel Venezuela’s illegal gold mining trade. Venezuela’s ‘blood gold’ is being smuggled, and Miami, the center of the anti-Maduro movement, sits at the very heart of the scheme. #SmugglersParadisehttps://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/venezuela/article230669164.html …

Why is Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro still in power? The country’s oil industry has collapsed, his people are starving and his government is increasingly isolated. But Maduro has one cash cow left: Gold. (THREAD) #SmugglersParadisepic.twitter.com/5Rk9fLtSmC

Read the full story here:https://hrld.us/2Xnm4Xe

“This kind of innovative housing solution will be the only way to solve the housing affordability crisis that we are currently facing,” said Albert Milo, president of Related Urban Development Group, which partnered with Miami-Dade County on the project.

When the final three phases are finished by 2023, the $300M Liberty Square development will house a total of 1,455 units of all price ranges, from public housing to market rate. Six blocks of the site have been rezoned to allow for commercial components such as a Publix.

Then came Saturday, when Gregory was handed the key to her one-bedroom apartment in the new Liberty Square. When she opened the door and saw the polished floors and shiny appliances, she burst into tears. Her rent remains the same as it was before — $147 per month.pic.twitter.com/I9oQhApEMP

So when developers came around 2 years ago with plans to replace the dilapidated homes of Liberty Square with new apartments, she didn’t believe them. “I knew they were not going to build anything like that for us. We’re public housing. They don’t do that for us.”

Liberty Square resident Sharon Gregory was skeptical. She had lived in a public housing unit for 17 years, tired and scared of the violence that has plagued one of the oldest housing projects in the U.S. (THREAD) https://hrld.us/2J3CZdk pic.twitter.com/5eEF5bDc5s

Activist Gail Colleta has asked lawmakers to consider lifting residency restrictions if an offender is a certain age or has ailments. “This is a humanity issue. … We’re more concerned about stray animals than we are about people with issues, that need to have medication.”

In Florida, counties and cities have different rules limiting where offenders can live. Miami-Dade and Broward counties are considered among the most restrictive. Both have a 2,500-foot residency restriction, which is less than half a mile.pic.twitter.com/4a4AtbNFeh
Sex offenders remain on the registry for life, meaning a young offender will continue to face the same restrictions in his or her senior years.

The problem is sparking a national crisis: How and where do we allow the most-reviled class of citizens to survive their silver years after they have served their prison terms, while striving to protect children?
People on Florida’s list of 73,000 registered offenders who are 65 and older are increasing, according to state data. Currently, Florida’s registry has about 10,200 elderly offenders.

“There’s no doubt that there’s a direct link between the violence and the closing of La Pampa,” Madre de Dios Gov. Luís Hidalgo Okimura said.pic.twitter.com/5kxt4qsIeR

In April, a tourist bus was held up at gunpoint near Madre de Dios’ capital, Puerto Maldonado, and in February, a nature lodge, full of Japanese sightseers, was robbed and one of the workers was murdered.
The result? A $69 million hole in Peru's economy ⁠— and a spike in crime that's bleeding into other parts of the country, affecting tourism.
So Peru's government shut down the gold fields. In the process, it also unveiled just how addicted the region had become to illegal mining.
The 40-square-mile area, known as La Pampa, used to be old-growth Amazon forest. Now, it's a toxic wasteland.pic.twitter.com/Cq9yVShLzq

. @NBPSEagles student Stacey Gringauz's nonprofit has raised $180,000 for charity. Yang also brought two Chinese-born tech executives to take $50k photos with Trump at a December 2017 RNC fundraiser. Neither paid for their seat directly. Reimbursing anyone for a ticket without full-disclosure would be illegal. So who paid?https://hrld.us/2YR4qNd
For example, a leader from the foreign arm of the Communist Party of China attended one of Yang’s Mar-a-Lago galas in 2018.https://hrld.us/2U38rzF

Yang has been making a name for herself by promoting her galas, selling them as opportunities for Chinese businessmen to gain face time with the Trump family. Lee bundled them into travel diplomacy packages sold in China. A breakdown of how that worked:https://hrld.us/2YD6ND8
Here's how Lee and Yang coordinate, as first reported by our team:pic.twitter.com/hjnXQFXei6

She also said she had been invited by a friend "Charles" – a known associate of Yang's in peddling access to Trump. Charles Lee claims to be both a prince and a member of a U.N. association. Neither appear true.

The woman arrested with malware was headed to an event advertised on Chinese social media by Yang. She said she wanted to use the club's pool, then said she wanted to discuss U.S.-China economic relations with a member of Trump's family, court records say.https://hrld.us/2YTduBx
We've been following these developments for the past few weeks. How are they all connected? Here’s what we know:
The investigation has also recently focused on Cindy Yang, sources tell us. She's the massage parlor entrepreneur-turned-Republican fundraising event promoter.

On Saturday, the probe took on higher urgency after Secret Service agents arrested a Chinese woman who tried to enter Mar-a-Lago with a thumb drive loaded with "malicious malware," plus four cellphones, an external hard-drive and a laptop.
That investigation has been going on for at least several months. It focused on Chinese nationals doing business in South Florida while potentially gathering intelligence for China's government.

So, how did Nibbs stay at the school for so long? @colleen_wright looked at how two powerful institutions — the United Teachers of Dade and Miami-Dade County Public Schools — dealt with 12 years of allegations against the veteran educator.https://hrld.us/2TxORpM
While his students filed complaint after complaint against him, Nibbs rose into the teachers union’s inner circle.

The girls who complained about Nibbs were already vulnerable. They were often in trouble, struggled academically and were overage for their grade. Many of them were bullied, and Nibbs is said to have comforted them and given them food.
The first complaint came in May 2004 when a 14-year-old girl told an assistant principal that Nibbs pulled her toward him and told her, "One day you’re going to be mine," while rubbing her waist.

Nibbs had already faced five allegations of sexual misconduct before he was arrested. That’s a total of nine students accusing the teacher of inappropriate behavior in the 15 years since he became a teacher.

As a result, we got accusations of voter fraud, protests and conspiracy theories. But there are steps the state could take to avoid all that. It starts with transparency. After all, what's at stake? Just voters' trust in the basic foundation of democracy.https://hrld.us/2StWJbD

Things were particularly bad in Broward County. Protesters called for Brenda Snipes' resignation after a mix-up with provisional ballots, a missed deadline to transmit recount results, and an admission that the county had misplaced 2,000 votes.https://hrld.us/2SvW0qo
This confused voters, and even caused Gov. Rick Scott to flip out after 60,000 additional votes were counted in left-leaning South Florida after election night.
4. Lack of transparency: Days after the election, the state couldn't explain how many votes had been rejected or even how many votes remained to be counted.

3. Old technology: Election officials have shied away from high-tech voting methods. It's almost taboo in an era of Russian hacking fears. But new hardware, software and databases exist that could make supervisors' lives easier. We look at some here:https://hrld.us/2SyFp5g
But bad ballot design is not a problem unique to Florida. There are really simple fixes we could learn from other states, like strengthening standards and implementing ballot-design review.

2. A flawed ballot design: In Broward County, some races were displayed below the printed instructions on the ballot. That design may have cost Bill Nelson the Senate race.https://hrld.us/2SwI9jt
Some argue that shifting to a completely mail-based system would save Florida money and avoid future chaos as voting by mail inevitably becomes more popular.

Voting by mail is incredibly popular. But experts say Florida will reach a tipping point where the time and effort to process those mail ballots will grow, and officials won't have enough time to count them all within the state's extremely tight deadlines.pic.twitter.com/3RfDyaTndu
1. A ton of absentee ballots: One in three ballots in 2018 were cast by mail, and that really complicated things for Florida. But what if the answer is… more mail-in voting?https://hrld.us/2Sz53GW

And the good news: The state has an opportunity to fix Florida's election woes before 2020. But lawmakers have to act. Yes, Florida's voting problems are very real, but they're hardly insurmountable.

In order to track 365 days of gun-related deaths #SinceParkland, @McClatchy and @teamtrace pulled data from @GunDeaths and compiled a database of law enforcement media and records contacts to request reports from more than 600 agencies.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article224957145.html …

Although Parkland seemed certain to change the parameters of the gun debate in America, 2018 looked a lot like 1929, when Americans were shocked and appalled by the St. Valentine’s Day Massacre, yet did little to alter their country’s gun law.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article224594280.html …

But no city, relative to its size, has been so scarred by gun violence as Delaware’s biggest city, Wilmington. It was dubbed “The Most Dangerous Place in America for Youth.”https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article226090070.html …

In Florida alone, there have been about 80 gun deaths — including the Parkland students — of youths 18 and under in the year #SinceParklandhttps://www.miamiherald.com/news/state/florida/article224898685.html …

#SinceParkland, more than 130 children were shot and killed in domestic situations — the vast majority being murder-suicides.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article224983580.html …

#SinceParkland, at least 150 children have died in accidental shootings. But do careless gun owners go to jail when their kids shoot themselves? Not always.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article225006255.html …
Most of these young people were not shot at school, but at home, on the street, with friends, or while riding bicycles. For example…

On the week of the anniversary of the #Parkland massacre, @teamtrace is publishing those portraits and @MiamiHerald and @McClatchy are presenting a series of stories on the year in gun violence against children. https://sinceparkland.org/about #SinceParkland

. @teamtrace wanted to acknowledge those lost lives. It assembled a team of more than 200 journalists — kids themselves — to research and write short portraits of every victim, 18 and under, for that 365-day period. https://sinceparkland.org/ #SinceParkland

That means that #SinceParkland, the United States have had enough young gun victims to fill three ultra-wide Boeing 777s, and the true number is certainly higher because no government agency keeps a real-time tally.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/national/article224680840.html …

After the shooting of 14 students and three adults at a Florida high school by a former student, parents and students rallied to say: Never again. “That time was revealing for me. I got squeezed,” Winslow said of that two-year period. “You squeeze a fruit or food or anything, you’re going to see what it’s made out of. I think the good times, the bad times that filled those years, they revealed the kind of person I am."pic.twitter.com/acQtprqEE0

Winslow returned to Miami for his fourth NBA season as a happier and more confident person. His improvement has been one of the most encouraging developments of a season that has the Heat in eighth place in the East.pic.twitter.com/99qmkQLPKW

For Winslow, it was his peers who inspired him to open up about his mental struggles. Mental health issues have been a topic of conversation around the NBA after stars like DeMar DeRozan and Kevin Love revealed stories about their own mental health battle.pic.twitter.com/s7H28aDfsa

“He doesn’t want to tell us because he doesn’t want us to worry,” his mom said. “But we can tell. You’re the baby of the family. We know when there’s something bothering you. We know what’s going on. It was a really dark time, especially when he had that surgery on his shoulder."
As the youngest of four, it was obvious to those around Winslow there was something weighing him down. Even when he remained quiet about the issues he was facing, they knew.

There was plenty of empathy from Winslow’s family and friends, though. But there was no intervention. There was only an open line of communication they made sure Winslow knew was there whenever he needed to talk about things.pic.twitter.com/vyICgiOloK
"There were times where it would be 3, 4 in the morning and I would just stay up until we went to breakfast the next morning and made sure he got to practice,” Rhodes said.

Derek Rhodes, who met and became close friends with Winslow while both attended Duke, lived with him during this two-year period. From quiet postgame dinners to sleepless nights to emotional conversations, it didn’t take long for Derek to realize something was off with Winslow.pic.twitter.com/YJYkL164Zb
“There were times when I didn’t know my place in this league or if I had a place or if I should go to the G League,” Winslow said.

This period in Winslow’s life began in the middle of 2016-17 when he suffered a shoulder injury that required surgery and cut his second NBA season short after just 18 games. And it continued in 2017-18 when his third NBA season didn’t live up to outside expectations.pic.twitter.com/0Wo00j1czC
His oldest brother described the previous two seasons as a “storm” and his mother called it “a really dark time” in Winslow’s life.

When asked about Arctic's abrupt dismissal, the village manager said his gig with police never officially existed. But emails obtained by the @MiamiHerald indicate otherwise.

Rather than barking, biting, or sniffing, the Siberian Husky's role was more therapeutic. One of Arctic's assignments: hanging out with the kids at a local middle school. They didn’t even get to say goodbye before his service was terminated.

"Sometimes [families] can't even afford to bring the bodies home," one attorney said.

For the families of these murdered women, closure is hard to come by. Relatives lack money to hire a lawyer or to travel to the place where the crime occurred, or even to make long-distance phone calls to investigators.https://hrld.us/2UjlI3A
In one case, an owner of a popular escort service flew a woman he met in Venezuela to Mexico to attend a wedding. "When she arrives, they seize her papers and force her into prostitution."
Many of these women, with dreams of becoming models, wind up working as escorts, or are forced into prostitution by human traffickers.https://hrld.us/2Ucry6y

"She put me in touch with a woman who ran prostitutes. I was forced to work like a dog, without money or food, until I escaped. She even held my passports. Then came the threats," said one woman who worked as an escort.
Finol's story is an alarming illustration of the risks surrounding the mass exodus of Venezuelans. "When one is willing to do anything, human trafficking can make its presence felt."

Some were murdered when they fell in with criminal groups or escort services. Others were killed by boyfriends and husbands. Other cases are still shrouded in mystery involving bodies that were never identified or claimed. Here are some of their stories: https://hrld.us/2UgTwOB pic.twitter.com/SfeZY6ioeu
Her story is not unusual. From February 2017 to November of this year, more than 40 Venezuelan women who fled home in search of a better life abroad have wound up dead.https://hrld.us/2UhwhnF

Kenny Finol was a young student when she left Venezuela, emigrating to Colombia and then Mexico. She returned home in a coffin. The 26-year-old had been disfigured with acid, brutally beaten, raped and tortured before she was killed.pic.twitter.com/bLDRh43kdl

. @jkbjournalist analyzed thousands of court records, lawsuits, witness depositions and FBI documents, filing motions in federal court and submitting FOIA requests. She and @EmilyMichot tracked down more than 60 women who say they were victims.https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/article221957120.html …

Several women who went to Epstein's home as underage girls are scheduled to testify against him for the first time. "These guys will get it in the end because us girls are not gonna sit here and just let this keep happening."pic.twitter.com/EeRNSOPblx

As with every case involving Epstein, this one could further embarrass his once-impressive roster of A-list friends and associations, which included Bill Clinton, President Trump and Prince Andrew. A guide to Epstein's inner circle:https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/article221897990.html …
Today, ongoing litigation could reveal more about #JeffreyEpstein's crimes and who was involved. A lawsuit is set for trial Dec. 4 in Palm Beach County.

He was allowed to leave for work release six days a week. His year of "house arrest" included trips to New York and the Virgin Islands. Part 3 of #PerversionofJustice:https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/article219494920.html …
Once behind bars, #JeffreyEpstein didn't go to state prison like most sex offenders in Florida. He didn’t even spend much time in his cell.

One victim, Courtney Wild, who was 14 when she met Epstein, is suing the federal government, alleging that prosecutors kept victims in the dark as part of a conspiracy to give Epstein one of the most lenient deals for a serial child sex abuser in history.pic.twitter.com/p9odz1Jm0K

On the morning of his sentencing, none of Epstein's victims were in the courtroom — and that was by design. The victims couldn't voice their objections or possibly sway the judge to give Epstein a harsher sentence or reject the plea agreement altogether.
That detective died in May. #PerversionofJustice Part 2:https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/article214210674.html …

"I always hoped that the plea would be thrown out and that these teenage girls, who were labeled as prostitutes by prosecutors, would get to finally shed that label and see him go to prison where he belongs," said one detective.

But they continued their work, finding evidence that supported the girls' allegations: Phone calls and messages like, "Tanya can't come at 7 p.m. tomorrow because she has soccer practice," and naked photographs of girls in Epstein's closet.pic.twitter.com/AtE7BY9lHE

Two police officers were willing to risk their careers to go after Epstein. They said they felt pressured by the state attorney to drop the investigation and downgrade it to a misdemeanor.pic.twitter.com/u5nd8mTabV

The pact Epstein negotiated with federal prosecutors was sealed so that no one — not even his victims — could know the full scope of his crimes. Court records, letters and emails show that the deal was negotiated, signed and executed behind victims' backs.
"She was was taken advantage of twice — first by Epstein, and then by the criminal justice system that labeled a 14-year-old girl as a prostitute," said the girl's lawyer.

The secretive deal allowed Epstein to quietly plead guilty to two felony prostitution charges. He admitted to committing only one offense against one underage girl, who was labeled a prostitute, even though she was just 14.

Documents show Acosta, then a federal prosecutor, didn't just buckle under pressure from Epstein's lawyers; he and other prosecutors worked *with* them to contain the case — even as the FBI was uncovering evidence of a wider sex trafficking operation.

Epstein could have spent life in prison, but he only served a little more than a year in jail. Why? A secret deal was struck — an extraordinary plea arrangement — with help from future Secretary of Labor Alex Acosta.pic.twitter.com/OFzvjGZJm0
The evidence police collected to support the victims' stories was impressive. "We had victims who didn't know each other, never met each other and they all basically told the same story."

What he did, according to interviews with victims and police, was lure girls, aged 13 to 16, to his mansion for a "massage." He would molest them, paying extra for oral sex and intercourse, and offering more money to bring him new girls, like an underage sex pyramid scheme.pic.twitter.com/cVAjM5zGDn

"I don't think anyone has been told the truth about what Jeffrey Epstein did," said Michelle Licata, now 30. "He ruined my life and a lot of girls' lives. People need to know what he did and why he wasn't prosecuted so it never happens again."pic.twitter.com/RCWvKdqYGX

Multimillionaire Jeffrey Epstein was accused of sexually assaulting dozens of teen girls. Their stories were dismissed by prosecutors, who cut Epstein a lenient deal. His victims have never had a voice, until now. Part 1 of #PerversionofJustice:https://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/article220097825.html …

Long before #MeToo became the catalyst for a women's movement about sexual assault — and a decade before the fall of Harvey Weinstein, Bill Cosby and U.S. Olympic gymnastic doctor Larry Nassar — there was Jeffrey Edward Epstein. #PerversionofJusticepic.twitter.com/z3rIvzQWE9

This #GivingTuesday, thank a military family in need. Every $10 you give erases $1,000 in unpaid medical bills — for good. To donate, go tohttps://hrld.us/2zN5171

The money we raise will be used specifically to buy and abolish the medical debt of servicemembers, veterans and their families around the country. Each family we help will receive a letter telling them their debt has been forgiven, and they never have to worry about it again.
We’ve launched The #WarWithin Initiative in partnership with @RIPMedicalDebt, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that buys medical debt in bulk, for pennies on the dollar — and erases it.

Did you know that military families frequently struggle with debt — and when they do, it raises their risk for depression, substance abuse and suicide? That equation affects a lot of people in the communities our newsrooms serve — and it’s one we can help change.pic.twitter.com/LpdGgF06Wy

The money we raise will be used specifically to buy and abolish the debt of servicemembers, veterans and their families across the country. Each family we help will receive a letter telling them their debt has been forgiven, and they never have to worry about it again.
We've launched The #WarWithin campaign in partnership with @RIPMedicalDebt, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that buys medical debt in bulk, for pennies on the dollar- and erases it.

Did you know that military families frequently struggle with debt - and when they do, it raises their risk for depression, substance abuse and suicide? That equation affects a lot of people in the communities our newsrooms serve - and it's one we can help change.pic.twitter.com/8NBycsyZh8

"It puts the power of screening in the hands of the woman." #CancerinHaitipic.twitter.com/mAGZZPyMyv

"Any time a community health worker would show up at the home of a woman whom she had previously set an appointment with, that woman had her aunt, her cousin, her sister ... there. Everyone wanted to do it." #CancerinHaiti

The researchers came up with a self-sampling kit that women could use in the privacy of their own homes. They gave Creole-speaking health workers the kit to see if Haitian immigrants would be receptive. #CancerinHaiti

"We're getting lumped into this broader category of black and it's distracting from an understanding on what our needs are, the challenges we have in accessing prevention," female community leaders said. #CancerinHaiti

While data suggested that black women received Pap smears in equal numbers to their white counterparts, that was not the case among Haitian women. They held negative perceptions about the test, including fears that their partners would not approve of it. #CancerinHaiti
When a UM researcher noticed an area of Northeast Miami-Dade had an unusually high rate of cervical cancer, that pocket of Miami turned out to be Little Haiti. #CancerinHaiti
In Miami's Little Haiti neighborhood, healthcare groups are working to reach Haitian women while addressing both cultural and access issues. #CancerinHaiti STORY:https://hrld.us/cancerinlittlehaiti …
Cultural barriers like that can even affect whether Haitian women living in the U.S. receive treatment. #CancerinHaiti

In some cases, health workers say, husbands have refused to allow their wives to be treated for precancerous lesions because it means abstaining from sex for two to four weeks afterward. #CancerinHaiti

With the factory program, women can be treated without losing a day's work, and they don’t have to tell their husbands or get them to pay for treatment in a society where women often need permission from their partners to take care of their own bodies. #CancerinHaitipic.twitter.com/hM5fmERclT

One way health workers are preventing cervical cancer? Treating women right inside the factories where they work, using rudimentary tools like smartphones and vinegar to test for abnormal cells. #CancerinHaiti STORY:https://hrld.us/cancerinhaitisolutions …

"The hardest part with any screening, specifically cervical cancer screening, is we're trying to convince a woman to take a test on a disease that she most likely won't have and if she does have, she most likely won't get symptoms for it for 10 years." #CancerinHaitipic.twitter.com/lXBcqnLSYI
Globally, there is an ongoing debate about how best to screen women for cervical cancer in low-resource countries like Haiti. #CancerinHaiti

"It is no longer acceptable for women in this country to keep dying from cervical cancer," one healthcare advocate said. "My biggest concern is: How are we protecting the lives of the new generation of girls?" #CancerinHaitihttps://hrld.us/cancerinhaiti

The HPV vaccine, which could stamp out cervical cancer in the country if given to girls and boys before they become sexually active, has been available since 2006. It is still mostly out of reach for Haitians. #CancerinHaiti

That's because in the entire country of 11M people, there is only one MRI scanner and no radiation machines. There are just three places in Haiti where the middle-class and poor have any hope of getting affordable care. That leaves most patients with few options. #CancerinHaiti
Women who can afford to travel abroad for treatment are the few who have a fighting chance against advanced forms of cervical cancer. #CancerinHaiti

Paul agonizes about what will happen to her children if she dies, especially her youngest, 6-year-old Marie Stacey, who she is considering putting in an orphanage to ensure she gets an education. #CancerinHaitipic.twitter.com/pDkMmonnf3

Paula Paul, 44, learned in April she has cervical cancer. She has accepted that the illness will take her life: "I already know that I am going to die — what else is there for me to do?" #CancerinHaitipic.twitter.com/YOVZlGA0Fu

"It is a preventable epidemic," said one doctor who has researched cervical cancer in Haiti for 25 years. "Honestly, nobody should die of this disease." And yet, cervical cancer is treated as a death sentence. #CancerinHaitipic.twitter.com/RGiNiRKmqb

Help lift a burden for those who serve. Every dollar you give forgives $100 worth of military medical debt. To donate, go tohttp://www.mcclatchy.com/warwithin

OK, but why focus on medical debt? Aren’t military families covered by the VA or through their military insurance? The short answer is: Not always. And when they're not, medical debt is a double burden for those who are often already carrying a lot.

Depression makes it harder to do daily tasks like pay bills, which can lead to debt and credit problems—and being in debt is linked to depression and despair. For individuals and families already dealing with the strains of reintegration, that cycle can have deadly consequences.

creditors and debt collectors who prey on members of the military—and a higher than average risk of depression among service members, veterans and their spouses are just some of the reasons. That last item is especially worth noting:
Why do military families wind up in debt? Low, fixed pay, plus the costs of frequent moves and deployments, bad financial advice, difficulties managing money from overseas, identity theft,
their families across the country. Each family we help will receive a letter telling them their debt has been forgiven, and they never have to worry about it again.

This #VeteransDay, we launched The #WarWithin campaign in partnership with @RIPMedicalDebt, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that buys medical debt in bulk, for pennies on the dollar—and erases it. The money we raise will be used to buy and abolish the debt of service members, veterans and

Did you know that military families frequently struggle with debt—and when they do, it raises their risk for depression, substance abuse and suicide? That equation affects a lot of people in the communities our newsrooms serve—and it's one we can help change.

Agriculture Commissioner race: Democrat Nikki Fried is leading Republican Matt Caldwell by just 575 votes. This morning, she trailed him by 4,000 votes. It's almost certain a manual recount is in store. #FloridaRecounthttps://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/election/article221362645.html …

Another thing about the Senate race: In Broward, questions are being raised about why so many fewer voters chose a candidate in that race. 24,763 voters appear to have skipped the Senate question, while still voting on the governor. #FloridaRecounthttps://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/election/article221344365.html …

Senate race: The margin between Republican Rick Scott and Democrat Bill Nelson continues to narrow. This race is headed to a recount. Nelson is still behind, but it's still possible he could win. #FloridaRecounthttps://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/election/article221355905.html …

Governor's race: Democrat Andrew Gillum continues to gain on Republican Ron DeSantis, but an unknown number of votes remain untallied. At the moment, the race is within the margin to trigger a recount: https://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/state-politics/article221342220.html … #FloridaRecount

There are now 3 statewide races within the margin to trigger a recount. They are: governor, U.S. Senate, and agriculture commissioner. Given Florida's history, the state will likely be under extraordinary scrutiny in the coming weeks. #FloridaRecounthttps://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/election/article221348405.html …
How does a recount even work? It's a little confusing. Here's a timeline: https://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/election/article221342415.html … #FloridaRecount

If you cast your ballot by mail/absentee, there's also info here on how to check the status of your ballot: https://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/state-politics/article221344555.html … #FloridaRecount

First, the most important thing: If you filled out a provisional ballot, you must contact your supervisor of elections by 5 p.m. Thursday to make sure your vote gets counted. More here: https://www.miamiherald.com/news/politics-government/state-politics/article221344555.html … #FloridaRecount

Mike Fernandez, of MBF Healthcare Partners, said this goal was a "pipe dream" without more education funding. "As long as we underfund education, we will have difficulty in the expansion of tax producing industries." #FLinfluencers
Diversifying Florida's economy starts with greater investments in education, infrastructure and tech, the #FLinfluencers said.

Meanwhile, the question on our readers' minds this week was: "How can Florida move forward beyond a tourism and services state in order to build a stronger and more inclusive economy?" So we asked the panel. #FLinfluencers #ReadLocal

One of the #FLinfluencers suggested Florida use a sliding scale rather than a single flat rate for all corporations. "Determining the appropriate corporate tax rate for Florida is a difficult balancing act," said @mcalonso305 of @unitedwaymiami. "There is no easy solution."

"I don't believe a change in the corporate tax rate, either up or down, is warranted at this time," said Brian Keeley, of @baptisthealthsf. "The Florida economy, in general, is currently doing just fine." #FLinfluencers

More than half of #FLinfluencers surveyed believe the state's current corporate tax rate of 5.5 percent shouldn't change. 25% said the rate should be raised to provide more funding for education, and 21% said it should be lowered to spur greater business development.

Read more of the #FLInfluencers’ insights on the state of Florida's higher education here.https://hrld.us/2RNTaxT
Some are concerned that Florida is lagging behind. "We need to try to be at level of California, Texas, New York, Michigan, Illinois, North Carolina," said Jorge Perez of @related_group.

The #FLInfluencers also stressed the importance of Florida having universities that can compete with the best in the country. “Having at least one premier university lifts up the entire system,” said @PresidentFuchs of @UF, the state’s highest rated university.

One influencer even proposed replacing the final year of college with internships. "This would be a good first step towards democratizing higher education and increasing the availability to reach a wider demographic market," said Jaret Davis, of @GT_Law. #FLInfluencers

The education system is "producing more college graduates with thousands of dollars in student loans while ignoring a growing need in the business community for skilled, vocational education graduates," said Brian Keeley, of @BaptistHealthSF. #FLInfluencers

As tuition and debt levels rise, Florida’s colleges need to place a greater emphasis on providing learning opportunities outside the classroom and increase vocational training. That was the main takeaway from our survey of #FLInfluencershttps://hrld.us/2RNTaxT

Puerto Rico's official death toll now stands at 2,975, making Maria one of the deadliest natural disasters in U.S. history. Watch our #ForgottenIsland mini-doc, with narration by @TheRitaMoreno: https://hrld.us/2ppS7a4 pic.twitter.com/PyBuV0zPyS

Special needs students have been hit particularly hard by the closures. Hundreds of parents were left struggling to find classrooms, teachers and therapists for children with autism, Down syndrome or cerebral palsy. #ForgottenIsland From @kyragurney:https://hrld.us/2pqo5mU

Now with many fewer children to educate (and virtually bankrupt), the government is controversially closing hundreds of underused public schools. #ForgottenIsland From @kyragurney:https://hrld.us/2poVvlT

The storm also quickened an exodus of younger people from the island, accentuating a demographic collapse that has left Puerto Rico with an aging population. #ForgottenIsland @jimwyss reports:https://hrld.us/2ppsPcw

For thousands with chronic diseases, life is still far from normal. @jimwyss followed one man with kidney disease, whose local hospital was infested with toxic mold. Three times a week, he makes a 10- to 12-hour trip for dialysis. #ForgottenIslandhttps://hrld.us/2po5Yha

The human toll, meanwhile, has been nearly incalculable. Suicide rates have jumped, and mental-health experts say cases of depression, diagnosed and not, are likely at epidemic levels. #ForgottenIsland From @jimwyss:https://hrld.us/2ppWulL

All of that means many legitimate homeowners have no way to satisfy FEM's requirements even when property has been in the family for generations, experts say. #ForgottenIslandpic.twitter.com/gjiORf2KFe

About 332,000 householders have been denied FEMA aid. The reason has to do with the informal nature of inheritance customs in PR, plus a legal code that carries the legacy of Spanish colonial rule. From @AndresViglucci: https://hrld.us/2pqj51C #ForgottenIsland

FEMA was already in the spotlight for contracting missteps involving botched delivery of food and tarps to Puerto Rico. But how do inexperienced companies keep winning contracts? #ForgottenIsland From @KevinGHall, @benbwieder and @ceostroff:https://hrld.us/2pq41kC

About 60,000 occupied homes remain roofless, and blue FEMA tarps have become a symbol of what many perceive as a woefully inadequate response by Trump's administration. On a bridge over a main artery in San Juan, stenciled graffiti reads "FEMA es el problema." #ForgottenIslandpic.twitter.com/SE1Fz1BqSX

Puerto Ricans have become weary of the blackouts. After Maria, clamor for electricity — of any kind — skyrocketed. Panicked islanders snapped up portable generators. Then a solar rush began. #ForgottenIslandhttps://hrld.us/2pnQycR

Power has been restored almost everywhere, an effort funded almost wholly by the federal government, but outages are common. The patched-up grid is still vulnerable to massive failure in the next storm. #ForgottenIsland From @TimJohnson4:https://hrld.us/2pmw1FA

To call the recovery uneven and uncertain doesn't begin to capture the true state of things. Stability remains a scarce commodity. Today we take a critical look at that recovery effort as part of our #ForgottenIsland series. Intro by @AndresViglucci: https://hrld.us/2po0bIs

As always, we invite you to submit questions for the #FLinfluencers via the Your Voice tool. Each week we choose a couple of questions to answer. This week, we want to know what Qs you have about Florida's criminal justice system. Tell us here https://hrld.us/2tO7lbD #ReadLocal

Meanwhile, we received a ton of questions from readers about how charter schools operate. One question we saw again and again was this: Are charter schools allowed to hire teachers who are not certified? Reporter @martindvassolo looked into it here:https://hrld.us/2peX71x

This week's question from readers for the #FLinfluencers was "Why are so many politicians interested in giving money to charter schools and taking money away from Florida public schools that need it more?" See where the they fell on that issue here:https://hrld.us/2D2Nsob

Some #FLinfluencers disagreed with that notion. "Charter schools are an answer to the failure of some school systems," said Mike Fernandez, of MBF Healthcare Partners. "We can't condemn our children because of an agenda to protect what does not work."

"I do believe children should have choices… but not at the expense of a public, non-profit education," said @SusanTowler, of @FLBlue. "I'm concerned we are disassembling public education with 'death by 1,000 cuts.'" #FLinfluencers

"Charter schools empower parents… and can also be hubs of experiential learning and innovation," said @MsFab_MIASocial, of @BlueprintCG_PR. "However, public school funding and transforming the current delivery of education should remain top priority." #FLinfluencers

Defenders of the law, such as @micafpc, of the Florida Petroleum Council, said that some "seem to be confused by the true extent of the actual law" and that "the existing law can work." Read more #FLInfluencers responses here:https://hrld.us/2MZXSZw

"SYG has a worthy intent, but it cannot be used as a shield for outright murder such as the [Trayvon] Martin case and the Tampa situation. A review of the law's practical application should be conducted," said Ken Lawson of @visitflorida. #FLInfluencers

"Stand Your Ground should be repealed in its entirety," said @ma_franks, of @MiamiLawSchool. "The ... movement was a fraud from the beginning, based on the false claim that law-abiding citizens were not permitted to defend themselves under existing law." #FLInfluencers

"The law is too vague and give[s] too much latitude to kill at will even in situation[s] where a safe retreat is possible and it is the right thing to do," said @MarleineBastien, executive director of @FANMOrg. #FLInfluencers

Black influencers, who make up a quarter of our #FLInfluencers group, unanimously agreed that Stand Your Ground should be revisited. Critics have called for the Legislature to review the measure, and many argue that black victims are disproportionately affected by the law.

We asked 50 of the state’s leaders whether Florida’s Stand Your Ground law should be reviewed by the Legislature. A majority said yes, but there was a clear split along racial/ethnic lines. https://hrld.us/2MZXSZw #FLInfluencers #ReadLocal

Aside from Medicaid expansion, 16 percent of the #FLInfluencers said creating a national "Medicare for All" system should be the top priority. Another 16 percent went in the other direction, calling for the complete repeal of the ACA.https://hrld.us/2wqqK36

"Healthcare is already 40 percent of our state budget. We can’t spend much more or other important services, like education, will suffer," said @AlCardenasFL_DC, of @SPB_Global. "Consider expanding Medicaid coverage without increasing eligibility opportunities." #FLInfluencers
A clear majority of the #FLInfluencers (69 percent) said Medicaid expansion is Florida's most pressing healthcare concern, but some worried about the costs associated with expansion.

"Because a person's health affects all aspects of their life, we urge the Florida Legislature and our next governor to prioritize this issue on their agenda and expand access to quality healthcare for all working families in Florida," said @mcalonso305, of @UnitedWayMiami.

Three years ago, state lawmakers considered several proposals to expand Medicaid that failed to advance due to opposition from the Republican-led House and Gov. Rick Scott, who is running for U.S. Senate this year. #FLInfluencers
Florida is one of 17 states that has not expanded Medicaid since 2014, and 12.5 percent of Floridians lack insurance, the third-highest rate in the nation. #FLInfluencers

In 2015, Florida lawmakers rejected a plan to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. Now a panel of Influencers is urging elected officials to expand it, calling it our most pressing healthcare matter. #FLInfluencers #ReadLocal https://hrld.us/2wqqK36

Just 7 percent of the #FLInfluencers said that no further action on guns issues was required. “They have gone far enough," said Carol Dover, president and CEO of @FRLAnews. "We must protect our constitutional rights."
"The Florida lawmakers did what they believe was sufficient," said Parkland survivor and activist @demichx. "However, this could not be further from the truth!" #FLInfluencers
Another 14 percent went even further, calling the change in Florida's laws an inadequate response to gun violence. #FLInfluencers

"We're off to a good start, but the issues are much deeper than gun access," said @SusanTowler, VP of @FLBlue, noting issues such as mental illness, family stability and poverty. "We should have a multi-level approach to these social determinants." #FLInfluencers
Nearly 80 percent of respondents our latest survey said that while they supported recent gun law changes, state officials need to do more to fully address the problem. #FLInfluencers

The measures Gov. Rick Scott signed into law after the Parkland massacre were an important first step, but lawmakers' work to protect schools and students is far from complete, according to most of the Florida Influencers polled. #FLInfluencers
